column1: Dynasties in Chinese history
column2: or Chinese dynasties
column3: were hereditary monarchical regimes that ruled over China during much of its history. From the inauguration of dynastic rule by Yu the Great in circa 2070 BC to the abdication of the Xuantong Emperor on 12 February 1912 in the wake of the Xinhai Revolution
column4: China was ruled by a series of successive dynasties. Dynasties of China were not limited to those established by ethnic Han—the dominant Chinese ethnic group—and its predecessor
column5: the Huaxia tribal confederation
column6: but also included those founded by non-Han peoples.Dividing Chinese history into periods ruled by dynasties is a common method of periodization utilized by scholars. Accordingly
column7: a dynasty may be used to delimit the era during which a family reigned
column8: as well as to describe events
column12: and artifacts of that period. For example
column13: a porcelain made during the Ming dynasty may be referred to as a "Ming porcelain". The word "dynasty" is usually omitted when making such adjectival references.

column1: Ruling for a total length of 789 years
column2: the longest-reigning orthodox dynasty of China was the Zhou dynasty
column3: albeit it is divided into the Western Zhou and the Eastern Zhou in Chinese historiography
column4: and its power was drastically reduced during the latter part of its rule. The largest orthodox Chinese dynasty in terms of territorial size was either the Yuan dynasty or the Qing dynasty
column5: depending on the historical source.Chinese dynasties often referred to themselves as "Tiāncháo" (天朝; "Celestial Dynasty" or "Heavenly Dynasty"). As a form of respect and subordination
column6: Chinese tributary states referred to Chinese dynasties as "Tiāncháo Shàngguó" (天朝上國; "Celestial Dynasty of the Lofty State") or "Tiāncháo Dàguó" (天朝大國; "Celestial Dynasty of the Great State").

column1: == Terminology ==
In the Chinese language
column2: the character "cháo" (朝) originally meant "morning" and "today". Politically
column3: the word is taken to refer to the regime of the incumbent ruler. The antonymic word is "yě" (野).

column1: The following is a list of terms associated with the concept of dynasty in Chinese historiography:
cháo (朝): a dynasty
cháodài (朝代): an era corresponding to the rule of a dynasty
wángcháo (王朝): while technically referring to royal dynasties
column2: this term is often inaccurately applied to all dynasties
column3: including those whose rulers held non-royal titles such as emperor

column1: huángcháo (皇朝): generally used for imperial dynasties
== History ==
=== Start of dynastic rule ===
As the founder of China's first dynasty
column2: the Xia dynasty
column3: Yu the Great is conventionally regarded as the inaugurator of dynastic rule in China. In the Chinese dynastic system
column4: sovereign rulers theoretically possessed absolute power and private ownership of the realm
column5: even though in practice their actual power was dependent on numerous factors. By tradition
column6: the Chinese throne was inherited exclusively through the male line
column7: but there were numerous cases whereby the consort kins came to possess de facto power at the expense of the monarchs. This concept
column8: known as jiā tiānxià (家天下; "All under Heaven belongs to the ruling family")
column9: was in contrast to the pre-Xia notion of gōng tiānxià (公天下; "All under Heaven belongs to the public") whereby leadership succession was non-hereditary.

column1: === Dynastic transition ===

The rise and fall of dynasties is a prominent feature of Chinese history. Some scholars have attempted to explain this phenomenon by attributing the success and failure of dynasties to the morality of the rulers
column2: while others have focused on the tangible aspects of monarchical rule. This method of explanation has come to be known as the dynastic cycle.Dynastic transitions (改朝換代; gǎi cháo huàn dài) in the history of China occurred primarily through two ways: military conquest and usurpation. The supersession of the Liao dynasty by the Jin dynasty was achieved following a series of successful military campaigns
column3: as was the later unification of China under the Yuan dynasty; on the other hand
column4: the transition from the Eastern Han to the Cao Wei
column5: as well as from the Southern Qi to the Liang dynasty
column7: usurpers would seek to portray their predecessors as having relinquished the throne willingly—a process called shànràng (禪讓; "voluntary abdication")—as a means to legitimize their rule.One  might incorrectly infer from viewing historical timelines that transitions between dynasties occurred abruptly and roughly. Rather
column8: new dynasties were often established before the complete overthrow of an existing regime. For example
column9: AD 1644 is frequently cited as the year in which the Qing dynasty succeeded the Ming dynasty in possessing the Mandate of Heaven. However
column10: the Qing dynasty was officially proclaimed in AD 1636 by the Emperor Taizong of Qing through renaming the Later Jin established by his father the Emperor Taizu of Qing in AD 1616
column11: while the Ming imperial family would rule the Southern Ming until AD 1662. The Ming loyalist Kingdom of Tungning based in Taiwan continued to oppose the Qing until AD 1683. Meanwhile
column12: other factions also fought for control over China during the Ming–Qing transition
column13: most notably the Shun and the Xi dynasties proclaimed by Li Zicheng and Zhang Xianzhong respectively. This change of ruling houses was a convoluted and prolonged affair
column14: and the Qing took almost two decades to extend their rule over the entirety of China proper.

column2: during the earlier Sui–Tang transition
column3: numerous regimes established by rebel forces vied for control and legitimacy as the power of the ruling Sui dynasty weakened. Autonomous regimes that existed during this period of upheaval included
column4: but not limited to
column5: Wei (魏; by Li Mi)
column16: and Song (宋; by Fu Gongshi). The Tang dynasty that superseded the Sui launched a decade-long military campaign to reunify China proper.Frequently
column17: remnants and descendants of previous dynasties were either purged or granted noble titles in accordance with the Èr Wáng Sān Kè (二王三恪; "two crownings
column18: three respects") system. The latter served as a means for the reigning dynasty to claim legitimate succession from earlier dynasties. For example
column19: the Emperor Xiaojing of Eastern Wei was accorded the title "Prince of Zhongshan" by the Emperor Wenxuan of Northern Qi following the latter's deposition of the former. Similarly
column21: a nephew of the Emperor Shizong of Later Zhou
column22: was conferred the title "Duke of Chongyi" by the Emperor Renzong of Song; other descendants of the Later Zhou ruling family came to inherit the noble title thereafter.According to Chinese historiographical tradition
column23: each new dynasty would compose the history of the preceding dynasty
column24: culminating in the Twenty-Four Histories. This tradition was maintained even after the Xinhai Revolution overthrew the Qing dynasty in favor of the Republic of China. However
column25: the attempt by the Republicans to draft the history of the Qing was disrupted by the Chinese Civil War
column26: which resulted in the political division of China into the People's Republic of China on mainland China and the Republic of China on Taiwan.

column1: === End of dynastic rule ===

Dynastic rule in China collapsed in AD 1912 when the Republic of China superseded the Qing dynasty following the success of the Xinhai Revolution. While there were attempts after the Xinhai Revolution to reinstate dynastic rule in China
column2: they were unsuccessful at consolidating their rule and gaining political legitimacy.

column1: During the Xinhai Revolution
column2: there were numerous proposals advocating for the replacement of the Manchu-led Qing dynasty by a new dynasty of Han ethnicity. Kong Lingyi (孔令貽)
column3: a 76th-generation descendant of Confucius and the holder of Duke Yansheng
column4: was identified as a potential candidate for Chinese emperorship by Liang Qichao. Meanwhile
column5: gentry in Anhui and Hebei supported a restoration of the Ming dynasty under Zhu Yuxun (朱煜勳)
column6: the Marquis of Extended Grace. Both suggestions were ultimately rejected.

column1: The Empire of China (AD 1915–1916) proclaimed by Yuan Shikai sparked the National Protection War
column2: resulting in the premature collapse of the regime 101 days later. The Manchu Restoration (AD 1917) was an unsuccessful attempt at reviving the Qing dynasty
column3: lasting merely 11 days. Similarly
column4: the Manchukuo (AD 1932–1945; monarchy since AD 1934)
column5: a puppet state of the Empire of Japan during World War II with limited diplomatic recognition
column6: is not regarded as a legitimate regime. Ergo
column7: historians usually consider the abdication of the Xuantong Emperor on 12 February 1912 as the end of the Chinese dynastic system. Dynastic rule in China lasted almost four millennia.

column1: == Political legitimacy ==
China was politically divided during multiple periods in its history
column2: with different regions ruled by different dynasties. These dynasties effectively functioned as separate states with their own court and political institutions. Political division existed during the Three Kingdoms
column3: the Sixteen Kingdoms
column4: the Northern and Southern dynasties
column5: and the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms periods

column1: Relations between Chinese dynasties during periods of division often revolved around political legitimacy
column2: which was derived from the doctrine of the Mandate of Heaven. Dynasties ruled by ethnic Han would proclaim rival dynasties founded by other ethnicities as illegitimate
column3: usually justified based on the concept of Hua–Yi distinction. On the other hand
column4: many dynasties of non-Han origin saw themselves as the legitimate dynasty of China and often sought to portray themselves as the true inheritor of Chinese culture and history. Traditionally
column5: only regimes deemed as "legitimate" or "orthodox" (正統; zhèngtǒng) are termed cháo (朝;  "dynasty"); "illegitimate" or "unorthodox" regimes are referred to as guó (國; usually translated as either "state" or "kingdom")
column6: even if these regimes were dynastic in nature. The issue of political legitimacy pertaining to some of these dynasties remains contentious in modern academia.

Both regimes formally adhere to the One-China policy and claim to be the sole legitimate representative of the whole of China.
== Agnatic lineages ==
There were several groups of Chinese dynasties that were ruled by families with patrilineal relations
column2: yet due to various reasons these regimes are considered to be separate dynasties and given separate retroactive names for historiographical purpose. Such conditions as differences in their official dynastic title and fundamental changes having occurred to their rule would create the need for nomenclatural distinction
column3: despite these dynasties sharing common ancestral origins.

column1: Additionally
column2: numerous other dynasties claimed descent from earlier dynasties as a calculated political move to obtain or enhance their legitimacy
column3: even if such claims were unfounded.

== Classification ==
=== Central Plain dynasties ===

The Central Plain is a vast area on the lower reaches of the Yellow River which formed the cradle of Chinese civilization. "Central Plain dynasties" (中原王朝; Zhōngyuán wángcháo) refer to dynasties of China that had their capital cities situated within the Central Plain. This term could refer to dynasties of both Han and non-Han ethnic origins.
=== Unified dynasties ===
Unified dynasties (大一統王朝; dàyītǒng wángcháo) refer to dynasties of China
column2: regardless of their ethnic origin
column3: that achieved the unification of China proper. "China proper" is a region generally regarded as the traditional heartland of the Han people
column4: and is not equivalent to the term "China". Imperial dynasties that had unified China proper may be known as the "Chinese Empire" or the "Empire of China" (中華帝國; Zhōnghuá Dìguó).The concept of "great unity" or "grand unification" (大一統; dàyītǒng) was first mentioned in the Chinese classical text Gongyang Commentary on the Spring and Autumn Annals that was supposedly authored by the Qi scholar Gongyang Gao. Other prominent figures like Confucius and Mencius also touched upon this concept in their respective works.Historians typically consider the following dynasties to have unified China proper: the Qin dynasty
column5: the Western Han
column15: and the Qing dynasty. The status of the Northern Song as a unified dynasty is disputed among historians as the Sixteen Prefectures of Yan and Yun were partially administered by the contemporaneous Liao dynasty while the Western Xia exercised partial control over Hetao; the Northern Song
column17: did not truly achieve the unification of China proper.

column1: === Conquest dynasties ===

Conquest dynasties (征服王朝; zhēngfú wángcháo) refer to dynasties of China founded by non-Han peoples that ruled parts or all of China proper. This term was first coined by the historian and sinologist Karl August Wittfogel and remains a source of controversy among scholars who believe that Chinese history should be analyzed and understood from a multiethnic and multicultural perspective. For instance
column2: the Northern Wei and the Qing dynasty
column3: established by the Xianbei and Manchu ethnicities respectively
column4: are considered conquest dynasties of China.

column1: == Naming convention ==
=== Official nomenclature ===
It was customary for Chinese monarchs to adopt an official name for the realm
column2: known as the guóhào (國號; "name of the state")
column3: upon the establishment of a dynasty. During the rule of a dynasty
column4: its guóhào functioned as the formal name of the state
column5: both internally and for diplomatic purposes.

column1: The formal name of Chinese dynasties was usually derived from one the following sources:
The name of the ruling tribe or tribal confederatione.g.
column2: the Xia dynasty took its name from its ruling class
column3: the Xia tribal confederation

column1: The noble title held by the dynastic founder prior to the founding of the dynastye.g.
column2: the Emperor Wu of Chen adopted the dynastic name "Chen" from his pre-imperial title "Prince of Chen" upon the establishment of the Chen dynasty

column1: The name of a historical state that occupied the same geographical location as the new dynastye.g.
column2: the Former Yan was officially named "Yan" based on the ancient State of Yan located in the same region

column1: The name of a previous dynasty from which the new dynasty claimed descent or succession from
column2: even if such familial link was questionablee.g.
column3: the Emperor Taizu of Later Zhou officially proclaimed the Later Zhou with the official title "Zhou" as he claimed ancestry from Guo Shu
column4: a royal of the Zhou dynasty

column1: A term with auspicious or other significant connotationse.g.
column2: the Yuan dynasty was officially the "Great Yuan"
column3: a name derived from a clause in the Classic of Changes
column4: "dà zāi Qián Yuán" (大哉乾元; "Great is the Heavenly and Primal")There were instances whereby the official name was changed during the reign of a dynasty. For example
column5: the dynasty known retroactively as Southern Han initially used the name "Yue"
column6: only to be renamed to "Han" subsequently.The official title of several dynasties bore the character "dà" (大; "great"). In Yongzhuang Xiaopin by the Ming historian Zhu Guozhen
column7: it was claimed that the first dynasty to do so was the Yuan dynasty. However
column8: several sources like the History of Liao and the History of Jin compiled by the Yuan historian Toqto'a revealed that the official dynastic name of some earlier dynasties such as the Liao and the Jin also contained the character "dà". It was also common for officials
column10: or tributary states of a particular dynasty to include the term "dà" (or an equivalent term in other languages) when referring to this dynasty as a form of respect
column11: even if the official dynastic name did not include it. For instance
column12: The Chronicles of Japan referred to the Tang dynasty as "Ōkara" (大唐; "Great Tang") despite its dynastic name being simply "Tang".

column1: While all dynasties of China sought to associate their respective realm with Zhōngguó (中國; "Central State"; usually translated as "Middle Kingdom" or "China" in English texts)
column2: none of these regimes officially used the term as their dynastic name. Although the Qing dynasty explicitly identified their state with and employed "Zhōngguó"—and its Manchu equivalent "Dulimbai Gurun" (ᡩᡠᠯᡳᠮᠪᠠᡳᡤᡠᡵᡠᠨ)—in official capacity in numerous international treaties beginning with the Treaty of Nerchinsk dated AD 1689
column3: its dynastic name had remained the "Great Qing". "Zhōngguó"
column4: which has become nearly synonymous with "China" in modern times
column5: is a concept with geographical
column7: and cultural connotations.The adoption of guóhào
column8: as well as the importance assigned to it
column9: had promulgated within the Sinosphere. Notably
column10: rulers of Vietnam and Korea also declared guóhào for their respective realm.

column1: === Retroactive nomenclature ===
In Chinese historiography
column2: historians generally do not refer to dynasties directly by their official name. Instead
column3: historiographical names
column4: which were most commonly derived from their official name
column5: are used. For instance
column6: the Sui dynasty is known as such because its formal name was "Sui". Likewise
column7: the Jin dynasty was officially the "Great Jin".

column1: When more than one dynasty shared the same Chinese character(s) as their formal name
column2: as was common in Chinese history
column3: prefixes are retroactively applied to dynastic names by historians in order to distinguish between these similarly-named regimes. Frequently used prefixes include:

column1: Cardinal direction
Northern (北; běi): e.g.
column2: Northern Qi
column3: Northern Yuan

column1: Southern (南; nán): e.g.
column2: Southern Yan
column3: Southern Tang

column1: Eastern (東; dōng): e.g.
column2: Eastern Jin
column3: Eastern Wei

column1: Western (西; xī): e.g.
column2: Western Liang
column3: Western Liao

column1: Sequence
Former (前; qián): e.g.
column2: Former Qin
column3: Former Shu

column1: Later (後; hòu): e.g.
column2: Later Zhao
column3: Later Han

column1: Surname of the ruling family
e.g.
column2: Wu Zhou
column3: Ma Chu

column1: Other types of prefixes
e.g.
column2: Shu Han (the prefix "Shu" is a reference to the realm's geographical location at Sichuan)
column3: Hu Xia (the prefix "Hu"
column4: meaning "barbarian"
column5: refers to the dynasty's Xiongnu origin)A dynasty could be referred to by more than one retroactive name in Chinese historiography
column6: albeit some are more widely used than others. For instance
column7: the Western Han is also known as the "Former Han"
column8: and the Yang Wu is also called the "Southern Wu".Scholars usually make a historiographical distinction for dynasties whose rule were interrupted. For example
column9: the Song dynasty is divided into the Northern Song and the Southern Song
column10: with the Jingkang Incident as the dividing line; the original "Song" founded by the Emperor Taizu of Song was therefore differentiated from the "Song" restored under the Emperor Gaozong of Song. In such cases
column12: only to be re-established; a nomenclatural distinction between the original regime and the new regime is thus necessary for historiographical purpose. Major exceptions to this historiographical practice include the Western Qin and the Tang dynasty
column13: which were interrupted by the Later Qin and the Wu Zhou respectively.In Chinese sources
column14: the term "dynasty" (朝; cháo) is usually omitted when referencing dynasties that have prefixes in their historiographical names. Such a practice is sometimes adopted in English usage
column15: even though the inclusion of the word "dynasty" is also widely seen in English scholarly writings. For example
column16: the Northern Zhou is also sometimes referred to as the "Northern Zhou dynasty".Often
column17: scholars would refer to a specific Chinese dynasty by adding the word "China" after the dynastic name. For instance
column18: "Tang China" refers to the Chinese state under the rule of the Tang dynasty and the corresponding historical era.

column1: == Territorial extent ==
While the earliest Chinese dynasties were established along the Yellow River and the Yangtze River in China proper
column2: numerous Chinese dynasties later expanded beyond the region to encompass other territorial domains.At various points in time
column3: Chinese dynasties exercised control over China proper (including Hainan
column4: Macau
column5: and Hong Kong)
column7: Manchuria (both Inner Manchuria and Outer Manchuria)
column9: Mongolia (both Inner Mongolia and Outer Mongolia)
column13: as well as parts of Central Asia
column17: the largest orthodox Chinese dynasty was either the Yuan dynasty or the Qing dynasty
column18: depending on the historical source. This discrepancy can be mainly attributed to the ambiguous northern border of the Yuan realm: whereas some sources describe the Yuan border as located to the immediate north of the northern shore of Lake Baikal
column19: others posit that the Yuan dynasty reached as far north as the Arctic coast. In contrast
column20: the borders of the Qing dynasty were demarcated and reinforced through a series of international treaties

column1: Apart from exerting direct control over the Chinese realm
column2: various dynasties of China also maintained hegemony over other states and tribes through the Chinese tributary system. The Chinese tributary system first emerged during the Western Han and lasted until the 19th century AD when the Sinocentric order broke down.The modern territorial claims of both the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China are inherited from the lands once held by the Qing dynasty at the time of its collapse.

This list includes only the major dynasties of China that are typically found in simplified forms of Chinese historical timelines. This list is neither comprehensive nor representative of Chinese history as a whole.
